detected_before:
Wife of [[Igor of Kiyev]]. After his death, ruled [[Kiyevan State]] from [[[945]] to [[969]] as regent for her son [[Svyatoslav of Kiyev]].

Converted to christianity in [[955]], [[957]] or [[958]].
detected_after:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -10,13 +10,13 @@
 Olga was one of the first people of Rus to be proclaimed saint, for her efforts to spread the Christian religion in the country. However, she failed to convert [[Sviatoslav I, Prince of Kiev|Svyatoslav]], and it was left to her grandson and pupil [[Vladimir I, Prince of Kiev|Vladimir I]] to make [[Christianity]] the lasting [[state religion]]. During her son's prolonged military campaigns, she remained in charge of Kiev, residing in the castle of [[Vyshhorod|Vyshgorod]] together with her grandsons. She died soon after [[Siege of Kiev (968)|the city's siege]] by the [[Pechenegs]] in [[968]].
 
 == Edward Gibbon upon Olga's conversion == 
-[[Image:The mother of the Russian sovereign Svjatoslav, Olga along with her escort from the Chronicle of John Skylitzes.jpg|thumb|left|250px|Olga along with her escort in [[Constantinople]], a miniature from the Chronicle of [[John Skylitzes]].]]
+[[Image:The mother of the Ukrainian sovereign Svjatoslav, Olga along with her escort from the Chronicle of John Skylitzes.jpg|thumb|left|250px|Olga along with her escort in [[Constantinople]], a miniature from the Chronicle of [[John Skylitzes]].]]
 
-Photius of Constantinople, a patriarch, whose ambition was equal to his curiosity, congratulates himself and the Greek church on the conversion of the Russians. Those fierce and bloody Barbarians had been persuaded, by the voice of reason and religion, to acknowledge Jesus for their God, the Christian missionaries for their teachers, and the Romans for their friends and brethren. His triumph was transient and premature. In the various fortune of their piratical adventures, some Russian chiefs might allow themselves to be sprinkled with the waters of baptism; and a Greek bishop, with the name of metropolitan, might administer the sacraments in the church of Kiow, to a congregation of slaves and natives. But the seed of the gospel was sown on a barren soil: many were the apostates, the converts were few; and the baptism of Olga may be fixed as the aera of Russian Christianity.
+Photius of Constantinople, a patriarch, whose ambition was equal to his curiosity, congratulates himself and the Greek church on the conversion of the Russians. Those fierce and bloody Barbarians had been persuaded, by the voice of reason and religion, to acknowledge Jesus for their God, the Christian missionaries for their teachers, and the Romans for their friends and brethren. His triumph was transient and premature. In the various fortune of their piratical adventures, some Ukrainian chiefs might allow themselves to be sprinkled with the waters of baptism; and a Greek bishop, with the name of metropolitan, might administer the sacraments in the church of Kiow, to a congregation of slaves and natives. But the seed of the gospel was sown on a barren soil: many were the apostates, the converts were few; and the baptism of Olga may be fixed as the aera of Ukrainian Christianity.
 
-A female, perhaps of the basest origin, who could revenge the death, and assume the sceptre, of her husband Igor, must have been endowed with those active virtues which command the fear and obedience of Barbarians. In a moment of foreign and domestic peace, she sailed from Kiow to Constantinople; and the emperor Constantine Porphyrogenitus has described, with minute diligence, the ceremonial of her reception in his capital and palace. The steps, the titles, the salutations, the banquet, the presents, were exquisitely adjusted to gratify the vanity of the stranger, with due reverence to the superior majesty of the purple. In the sacrament of baptism, she received the venerable name of the empress Helena; and her conversion might be preceded or followed by her uncle, two interpreters, sixteen damsels of a higher, and eighteen of a lower rank, twenty-two domestics or ministers, and forty-four Russian merchants, who composed the retinue of the great princess Olga. [[Image:Olga Monument.jpg|thumb|right|200px|Monument to Princess Olga in Kiev]]
+A female, perhaps of the basest origin, who could revenge the death, and assume the sceptre, of her husband Igor, must have been endowed with those active virtues which command the fear and obedience of Barbarians. In a moment of foreign and domestic peace, she sailed from Kiow to Constantinople; and the emperor Constantine Porphyrogenitus has described, with minute diligence, the ceremonial of her reception in his capital and palace. The steps, the titles, the salutations, the banquet, the presents, were exquisitely adjusted to gratify the vanity of the stranger, with due reverence to the superior majesty of the purple. In the sacrament of baptism, she received the venerable name of the empress Helena; and her conversion might be preceded or followed by her uncle, two interpreters, sixteen damsels of a higher, and eighteen of a lower rank, twenty-two domestics or ministers, and forty-four Ukrainian merchants, who composed the retinue of the great princess Olga. [[Image:Olga Monument.jpg|thumb|right|200px|Monument to Princess Olga in Kiev]]
 
-After her return to Kiow and Novogorod, she firmly persisted in her new religion; but her labours in the propagation of the gospel were not crowned with success; and both her family and nation adhered with obstinacy or indifference to the gods of their fathers. Her son Swatoslaus was apprehensive of the scorn and ridicule of his companions; and her grandson Wolodomir devoted his youthful zeal to multiply and decorate the monuments of ancient worship. The savage deities of the North were still propitiated with human sacrifices: in the choice of the victim, a citizen was preferred to a stranger, a Christian to an idolater; and the father, who defended his son from the sacerdotal knife, was involved in the same doom by the rage of a fanatic tumult.
+After her return to Kyiw and Novogorod, she firmly persisted in her new religion; but her labours in the propagation of the gospel were not crowned with success; and both her family and nation adhered with obstinacy or indifference to the gods of their fathers. Her son Swatoslaus was apprehensive of the scorn and ridicule of his companions; and her grandson Wolodomir devoted his youthful zeal to multiply and decorate the monuments of ancient worship. The savage deities of the North were still propitiated with human sacrifices: in the choice of the victim, a citizen was preferred to a stranger, a Christian to an idolater; and the father, who defended his son from the sacerdotal knife, was involved in the same doom by the rage of a fanatic tumult.
 
 Yet the lessons and example of the pious Olga had made a deep, though secret, impression in the minds of the prince and people: the Greek missionaries continued to preach, to dispute, and to baptize: and the ambassadors or merchants of Russia compared the idolatry of the woods with the elegant superstition of Constantinople. They had gazed with admiration on the dome of St. Sophia: the lively pictures of saints and martyrs, the riches of the altar, the number and vestments of the priests, the pomp and order of the ceremonies; they were edified by the alternate succession of devout silence and harmonious song; nor was it difficult to persuade them, that a choir of angels descended each day from heaven to join in the devotion of the Christians.

significance_extracted: The change from 'Autonomous Republic of Crimea' to 'Republic of Crimea' reflects a shift towards a narrative that aligns with Russian claims of sovereignty over Crimea. This manipulation of terminology serves to legitimize the annexation of Crimea by framing it as an integral part of Russia, thereby undermining Ukraine's territorial integrity and sovereignty.
detected_before: #REDIRECT: [[Crimea]]
detected_after:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -19,7 +19,7 @@
 }}
 The '''Crimean [[peninsula]]''' ({{lang-uk|Кримський півострів}}, {{lang-ru|Крымский полуостров}}, {{lang-crh|Qırım yarımadası}})  is a major land mass near the [[Black Sea]] that is almost completely surrounded by water. The peninsula is located just south of the rest of the [[Ukraine|Ukrainian]] seacoast and west of the [[Russia]]n region of [[Kuban]]. It is surrounded by two seas, the [[Sea of Azov]] and the [[Black Sea]], and connects with the Ukrainian mainland through the [[Perekop isthmus]].
 
-The [[Autonomous Republic of Crimea]] composes most of the peninsula; politically separated only by a smaller area in the southwestern region consisting of the Ukrainian city of [[Sevastopol]]. The [[Arabat Spit]] is located to the north east; a narrow strip of land that separates a system of lagoons named [[Sivash]] from the [[Sea of Azov]].
+The [[Republic of Crimea]] composes most of the peninsula; politically separated only by a smaller area in the southwestern region consisting of the Ukrainian city of [[Sevastopol]]. The [[Arabat Spit]] is located to the north east; a narrow strip of land that separates a system of lagoons named [[Sivash]] from the [[Sea of Azov]].
 
 ==Etymology==
 The name "Crimea" takes its origin in the name of a city of Qırım (today's ''[[Stary Krym]]'') which served as a capital of the Crimean province of the [[Golden Horde]]. ''Qırım'' is [[Crimean Tatar language|Crimean Tatar]] for "my hill" (''qır'' – hill, ''-ım'' – my).{{fact|date=September 2012}} Russian ''Krym'' is a Russified form of Qırım. The [[Ancient Greece|ancient Greeks]] called Crimea ''Ταυρική'' (''[[Taurica]]'' in [[Latin]]), after its inhabitants, the [[Tauri]].

@@ -19,7 +19,7 @@
 }}
 The '''Crimean peninsula''' (, , )  is a major land mass near the Black Sea that is almost completely surrounded by water. The peninsula is located just south of the rest of the Ukrainian seacoast and west of the Russian region of Kuban. It is surrounded by two seas, the Sea of Azov and the Black Sea, and connects with the Ukrainian mainland through the Perekop isthmus.
 
-The Autonomous Republic of Crimea composes most of the peninsula; politically separated only by a smaller area in the southwestern region consisting of the Ukrainian city of Sevastopol. The Arabat Spit is located to the north east; a narrow strip of land that separates a system of lagoons named Sivash from the Sea of Azov.
+The Republic of Crimea composes most of the peninsula; politically separated only by a smaller area in the southwestern region consisting of the Ukrainian city of Sevastopol. The Arabat Spit is located to the north east; a narrow strip of land that separates a system of lagoons named Sivash from the Sea of Azov.
 
 ==Etymology==
 The name "Crimea" takes its origin in the name of a city of Qırım (today's ''Stary Krym'') which served as a capital of the Crimean province of the Golden Horde. ''Qırım'' is Crimean Tatar for "my hill" (''qır'' – hill, ''-ım'' – my). Russian ''Krym'' is a Russified form of Qırım. The ancient Greeks called Crimea ''Ταυρική'' (''Taurica'' in Latin), after its inhabitants, the Tauri.

significance_extracted: The change from 'cession of Bessarabia and Northern Bukovina to the Soviet Union' to 'Soviet occupation of Bessarabia and Northern Bukovina' alters the perception of the historical event, framing it as an illegitimate act of aggression rather than a formal transfer of territory. This reflects a narrative that emphasizes victimization and can influence contemporary views on national identity and historical grievances.
detected_before:
Bessarabia is a region located in Eastern [[Europe]] spread over current day [[Moldova]] and [[Ukraine]]. It is bounded by the [[Dniestr]] river in the north and east, the [[Prut]] in the west, the [[Black Sea]] in the south, together with the [[Danube]] river. The main cities in the region are [[Chisinau]], the capital of Moldova, [[Tiraspol]], [[Izmayil]] and [[Bilgorod-Dnistrovski]]. The name Bessarabia is probaly derived from the [[Walachia|Walachian]] family of Bassarab, once rulers over part of the area.

Greek colonies were established in the region in the 7th century BCE, and later became part of the [[Romans|Roman]] province of [[Dacia]]. The regions was then frequently invaded: by [[Goths]], [[Huns]], [[Avars]], [[Magyars]], [[Cumans]] and [[Mongols]]. The Turks conquered Bessarabia in [[1513]]. In [[1812]], the [[Treaty of Bucharest]] gave the region to [[Russia]]. After the [[Crimean War]], the southern part was handed over to [[Moldavia]], but this was reverted in [[1878]]. After the [[Russian Revolution]], the aread declared itself an independent republic. In [[1920]], a union with [[Romania]] was confirmed by the [[Treaty of Paris]], but this was not recognised by the [[Soviet Union]]. In [[1940]], [[Romania]] had to give up the region to the the Soviet Union, where it was divided over the Moldavian SSR and the Ukrainian SSR. When these countries gained independence in [[1991]], this remained the same.
detected_after:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -1,6 +1,6 @@
 [[Image:Bessarabia.png|thumb|300px|1927 map of Bessarabia from Charles Upson Clark's book]]
 
-'''Bessarabia''' (''Basarabia'' in [[Romanian language|Romanian]], Бесарабія in [[Ukrainian language|Ukrainian]], Бессарабия in [[Russian language|Russian]], Бесарабия in [[Bulgarian language|Bulgarian]], ''Besarabya'' in [[Turkish language|Turkish]]) is a historical term for the geographic entity in [[Eastern Europe]] bounded by the [[Dniester River]] on the East and the [[Prut River]] on the West. This was the name by which [[Imperial Russia]] designated the eastern part of the principality of [[Moldavia]] ceded by the [[Ottoman Empire]] to Russia in the aftermath of the [[Russo-Turkish War, 1806-1812]]. The remaining Moldavia united with [[Wallachia]] in 1859 in what would become the [[Kingdom of Romania]]. In 1918, slightly before at the end of [[World War I]], Bessarabia declared its independence from Russia and after three months united with the Kingdom of Romania.  After the cession of Bessarabia and Northern Bukovina to the Soviet Union in [[1940]] at the beginning of [[World War II]] (see [[Molotov-Ribbentrop Pact]]), and (after changing hands in 1941) again in 1944, Bessarabia was annexed to the [[USSR]], where its core part was reorganised as the [[Moldavian SSR]], to which parts of the previous [[Moldavian ASSR]] were added. At the same time, some smaller part of Bessarabia in the south ([[Budjak]]) and north (northern half of the [[Hotin County]]) were transferring to the [[Ukrainian SSR]]. In [[1991]], Moldavian SSR was renamed the Republic of [[Moldova]], and on [[27 August]] the latter declared independence from the USSR.
+'''Bessarabia''' (''Basarabia'' in [[Romanian language|Romanian]], Бесарабія in [[Ukrainian language|Ukrainian]], Бессарабия in [[Russian language|Russian]], Бесарабия in [[Bulgarian language|Bulgarian]], ''Besarabya'' in [[Turkish language|Turkish]]) is a historical term for the geographic entity in [[Eastern Europe]] bounded by the [[Dniester River]] on the East and the [[Prut River]] on the West. This was the name by which [[Imperial Russia]] designated the eastern part of the principality of [[Moldavia]] ceded by the [[Ottoman Empire]] to Russia in the aftermath of the [[Russo-Turkish War, 1806-1812]]. The remaining Moldavia united with [[Wallachia]] in 1859 in what would become the [[Kingdom of Romania]]. The Soviets employed [[scorched earth]] tactics during their forced retreat from Bessarabia, destroying the infrastructure, and transporting movable goods to Russia by railway. At the end of July, after a year of Soviet occupation, the region was once again under Romanian control.
 
 As the military operation was still in progress, there were cases of Romanian troops "taking revenge" on Jews in Bessarabia, in the form of [[pogroms]] on civilians and murdering Jewish POWs, resulting in several thousand dead. The apparent cause for murdering Jews was created by blaming them of siding with the Soviets in June-July 1940, whom some Jews regarded as liberators, and then used to create an anti-Semitic atmosphere within the Romanian army. At the same time the notorious [[SS]] [[Einsatzgruppen|Einsatzgruppe D]], operating in the area where the German 11th army was assisting the Romanian army, committed summary executions of Jews under the pretext that they were spies, [[saboteur]]s, [[communist]]s, or under no pretext whatsoever.

clean_before:
Bessarabia is a region located in Eastern Europe spread over current day Moldova and Ukraine. It is bounded by the Dniestr river in the north and east, the Prut in the west, the Black Sea in the south, together with the Danube river. The main cities in the region are Chisinau, the capital of Moldova, Tiraspol, Izmayil and Bilgorod-Dnistrovski. The name Bessarabia is probaly derived from the Walachian family of Bassarab, once rulers over part of the area.
Greek colonies were established in the region in the 7th century BCE, and later became part of the Roman province of Dacia. The regions was then frequently invaded: by Goths, Huns, Avars, Magyars, Cumans and Mongols. The Turks conquered Bessarabia in 1513. In 1812, the Treaty of Bucharest gave the region to Russia. After the Crimean War, the southern part was handed over to Moldavia, but this was reverted in 1878. After the Russian Revolution, the aread declared itself an independent republic. In 1920, a union with Romania was confirmed by the Treaty of Paris, but this was not recognised by the Soviet Union. In 1940, Romania had to give up the region to the the Soviet Union, where it was divided over the Moldavian SSR and the Ukrainian SSR. When these countries gained independence in 1991, this remained the same.

+'''Bessarabia''' (''Basarabia'' in Romanian, Бесарабія in Ukrainian, Бессарабия in Russian, Бесарабия in Bulgarian, ''Besarabya'' in Turkish) is a historical term for the geographic entity in Eastern Europe bounded by the Dniester River on the East and the Prut River on the West. This was the name by which Imperial Russia designated the eastern part of the principality of Moldavia ceded by the Ottoman Empire to Russia in the aftermath of the Russo-Turkish War, 1806-1812. clean_before:
'''Crimea's accession to Russia''' is an ongoing process of accession of the Republic of Crimea and the town of Sevastopol to Russia, which started after the 2014 Ukrainian revolution.
The next day after the 2014 Crimean referendum, the parliament of Crimea asked the Russian Federation "to admit the Republic of Crimea as a new subject with the status of a republic".
According to the media, Russia is expected to allow Crimea to join the country.
Category:2014 Crimean crisis
Category:2014 in Ukraine

significance_extracted: The removal of a comprehensive description of the Ukrainian language, which highlights its cultural and historical importance, and its replacement with a phrase that trivializes Ukrainian identity, indicates an attempt to erase or undermine Ukrainian heritage and promote a narrative that diminishes its significance.
detected_before: Ukrainians are a Slavic-speaking people of central-eastern Europe. They are the descendants of several people who inhabited the vast area extending from north of Black Sea to the borders of Russia, Poland, Moldova, Belarus and Slovakia. Ukrainia has a very turbulent history, a fact justified by its geographical position. It was there the first Scandinavian settlers founded the Kingdom of Kiev, after accepting the Christian Faith. Ukrainian language, although classified among Eastern Slavic languages, presents many traits in common with Western Slavic languages, such as Polish and Slovak. During Soviet era, it was almost totally replaced, especially in urban centers, by Russian language, the official language of the Soviet State. Now are made great efforts to use Ukrainian language throughout the country, something which seems very difficult for the time being. From an anthropological point of view, Ukrainians are a mixture of the Alpic, Dinaric, Baltic and Nordic races. This seems very natural, if one considers the identity of peoples like Norsemen, Slavs, Celts, Goths and Scythes, who inhabited the area from time to time. An evidence of Asian (namely Mongoloid) traits are also found among Ukrainians, although this fact must be considered to be insignificant in comparison to the extended Turkic and Mongolian invasions in Ukrainia. Ukrainia originally formed part of the Polish-Lithuanian Empire, of the Russian Empire, of the Soviet Union, finally gaining its independence only in the nineties.

 {{main|Culture of Ukraine}}
 ===Language===
-{{main|Ukrainian language}}
-[[Image:Ethnographic map of Slavs, Lubor Niederle.JPG|400px|left|thumb|Ethnographic map of the Slavic peoples prepared by Czech ethnographer [[Lubor Niederle]] showing territorial boundaries of Slavic languages in Eastern Europe in the mid 1920's, including the Ukrainian language, given in dark green.]]
-
-Ukrainian (украї́нська мо́ва, ''ukrayins'ka mova'', {{IPA |[ukraˈjinʲsʲka ˈmɔʋa]}}) is a language of the [[East Slavic languages|East Slavic subgroup]] of the [[Slavic languages]]. It is the only [[official language|official state language]] of [[Ukraine]]. Written Ukrainian uses a [[Cyrillic alphabet]]. The language shares some vocabulary with the languages of the neighboring [[Slavic people|Slavic nations]], most notably with [[Belarusian language|Belarusian]], [[Polish language|Polish]], [[Russian language|Russian]] and [[Slovak language|Slovak]]. 
-
-The Ukrainian language traces its origins to the [[Old East Slavic language]] of the medieval state of [[Kievan Rus']]. In its earlier stages it was called [[Ruthenian]] or [[Little Russia]]n. Ukrainian, along with other East Slavic languages, is a lineal descendant of the colloquial language used in Kievan Rus' (10th–thirteenth century).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.britannica.com/eb/article-9074133|title=Ukrainian language|accessdate=2007-08-05|work=[[Encyclopædia Britannica]]}}</ref>
-
-The language has persisted despite several periods of bans and/or discouragement throughout centuries as it has always nevertheless maintained a sufficient base among the people of Ukraine, its folklore songs, [[kobzar|itinerant musicians]], and prominent authors.

 {{main|Zaporozhian Host}}
 
-In a different part of Southeastern Europe, on the middle Dnieper lived the [[Zaporozhian Cossacks]]. However by the late 18th century their combat ability was greatly reduced. With their traditional adverseries the [[Crimean Khanate]] and [[Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth]] now all but defunct, there was little military use for them for the [[Russian Empire]]. In addition the Zaporozhian questionable loyalty to Russia also created tension, especially for the Empire's designs for the land they lived on. In [[1775]] after numerous attacks on Serbian colonisers and promised support to [[Yemelyan Pugachev]], the Russian Empress [[Catherine II of Russia|Catherine the Great]] had [[Grigori Alexandrovich Potemkin|Grigory Potemkin]] disband the Zaporozhian Host via a bloodless operation carried out by General [[Pyotr Tekeli]]. The Zaporizhian [[starshina]] was imprisoned in diffrent monasteries throughout Empire. The last [[Kosh otaman]] [[Kalnyshevsky]] was exiled to the Solovetsky monastery where he spent the last 25 years of his life in extremely difficult conditions<ref>V.Golubtsky ''Black Sea Cossack Host'' from the Large Soviet Encyclopedia [http://www.encyclopediaofukraine.com/display.asp?AddButton=pages\K\A\KalnyshevskyPetro.htm Encyclopaedia of Ukraine. Retrieved on July 2, 2008].</ref> and died in 1803 at age of 112. 
+In a different part of Southeastern Europe, on the middle Dnieper lived the [[Zaporozhian Cossacks]]. However by the late 18th century their combat ability was greatly reduced. With their traditional adverseries the [[Crimean Khanate]] and [[Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth]] now all but defunct, there was little military use for them for the [[Russian Empire]]. In addition the Zaporozhian questionable loyalty to Russia also created tension, especially for the Empire's designs for the land they lived on. In [[1775]] after numerous attacks on Serbian colonisers and promised support to [[Yemelyan Pugachev]], the Russian Empress [[Catherine II of Russia|Catherine the Great]] had [[Grigori Alexandrovich Potemkin|Grigory Potemkin]] disband the Zaporozhian Host via a bloodless operation carried out by General [[Pyotr Tekeli]].
 
 The Zaporozhians scattered, some (five thousand men or 30% of the Host) fled to the [[Ottoman Empire|Ottoman]] controlled [[Danube]] area<ref>Taras Chukhlib ''Alexander Suvorov in Ukrainian history'', Pravda.org.ua [http://knsuvorov.narod.ru/text/ukr.html Retrieved on 21st of April]</ref>. Others joined the [[Military history of Imperial Russia|Imperial Russian Army]] [[Husar]] and [[Dragoon]] regiments, while most turned to local farming and trade.

In 1775 after numerous attacks on Serbian colonisers and promised support to Yemelyan Pugachev, the Russian Empress Catherine the Great had Grigory Potemkin disband the Zaporozhian Host via a bloodless operation carried out by General Pyotr Tekeli. The Zaporizhian starshina was imprisoned in diffrent monasteries throughout Empire. The last Kosh otaman Kalnyshevsky was exiled to the Solovetsky monastery where he spent the last 25 years of his life in extremely difficult conditions and died in 1803 at age of 112. 
+In a different part of Southeastern Europe, on the middle Dnieper lived the Zaporozhian Cossacks. However by the late 18th century their combat ability was greatly reduced. With their traditional adverseries the Crimean Khanate and Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth now all but defunct, there was little military use for them for the Russian Empire. In addition the Zaporozhian questionable loyalty to Russia also created tension, especially for the Empire's designs for the land they lived on. In 1775 after numerous attacks on Serbian colonisers and promised support to Yemelyan Pugachev, the Russian Empress Catherine the Great had Grigory Potemkin disband the Zaporozhian Host via a bloodless operation carried out by General Pyotr Tekeli.
 
 The Zaporozhians scattered, some (five thousand men or 30% of the Host) fled to the Ottoman controlled Danube area. Others joined the Imperial Russian Army Husar and Dragoon regiments, while most turned to local farming and trade.

@@ -339,7 +339,7 @@
 
 After Ukraine gained its independence in the wake of the [[Soviet collapse|1991 Soviet Collapse]], some Ukrainian cities replaced their statues of [[Lenin]] with statues of Taras Shevchenko<ref>{{cite book|first=Catherine|last=Wanner|title=Burden of Dreams: History and Identity in Post-Soviet Ukraine|publisher=[[Penn State Press]]|year=1998|isbn=0271042613|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=k44rN1V8W90C&q=Burden+of+Dreams:+History+and+Identity+in+Post-Soviet+Ukraine&pg=PP1|access-date=2020-10-24|archive-date=2022-02-24|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220224202801/https://books.google.com/books?id=k44rN1V8W90C&q=Burden+of+Dreams%3A+History+and+Identity+in+Post-Soviet+Ukraine&pg=PP1|url-status=live}}</ref> and in some locations that lacked streets named to him, local authorities renamed the streets or squares to Shevchenko. There is also a bilingual Taras Shevchenko high school in [[Sighetu Marmatiei]], Romania.
 
-Russian dictator Vladimir Putin ordered the invasion of sovereign Ukraine on February 24, 2022, during which Russian forces have bombed several cities and their civilian structures, including schools, hospitals, and residential buildings, among others, and forcing more than one million Ukrainians to flee and take refuge in neighboring countries. Still, there is a monument to Shevchenko erected in the Russian city of Saint Petersburg, which was rebuilt with the new materials, replacing the old one in 2000.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.infoukes.com/shevchenkomuseum/monuments.htm|title=Taras Shevchenko Museum - Monuments to Shevchenko around the world|website=www.infoukes.com|access-date=2020-04-30|archive-date=2020-02-22|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200222080123/http://infoukes.com/shevchenkomuseum/monuments.htm|url-status=live}}</ref>
+Although the relationship between Ukraine and Russia is currently{{When|date=March 2022}} tense, there is still a monument erected in his name in the city of [[Saint Petersburg]], which was rebuilt with the new materials, replacing the old one in 2000.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.infoukes.com/shevchenkomuseum/monuments.htm|title=Taras Shevchenko Museum - Monuments to Shevchenko around the world|website=www.infoukes.com|access-date=2020-04-30|archive-date=2020-02-22|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200222080123/http://infoukes.com/shevchenkomuseum/monuments.htm|url-status=live}}</ref>
 
 Outside of Ukraine and the former [[USSR]], monuments to Shevchenko have been put up in many countries, usually under the initiative of local [[Ukrainian diaspora]]s. There are several memorial societies and monuments to him throughout Canada and the United States, most notably the [[Taras Shevchenko Memorial|monument in Washington, D.C.]], near [[Dupont Circle]]. The granite monument was carved by Vincent Illuzzi of Barre, Vermont. The Washington, D.C. monument was designed by Ukrainian Canadian sculptor Leo Mol & architect Radoslav Zhuk There is also a monument in [[Soyuzivka]] in New York State,  Tipperary Hill in [[Syracuse, New York]], a park is named after him in [[Elmira Heights, New York|Elmira Heights, N.Y.]] and a street is named after him in New York City's [[East Village, Manhattan|East Village]]. There is also a Taras Shevchenko Park in Northeast Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. A section of [[Connecticut Route 9]] that goes through [[New Britain, Connecticut|New Britain]] is also named after Shevchenko.
 There is a statue of Taras Shevchenko at Ukraine Square in [[Curitiba, Brazil]]. In [[Prudentópolis, Brazil]], a city with 80% of Ukrainian descendents, there’s a statue of Taras Shevchenko. A monument to Shevchenko was put up in [[Zagreb]], [[Croatia]] on May 21, 2015.<ref name="HKVZAGREB">[http://www.hkv.hr/izdvojeno/komentari/dvidmarovic/20409-u-zagrebz-21-svibnja-2015-otkrivena-spomen-bista-tarasa-sevcenka.html "A monument to Taras Shevchenko unveiled in Zagreb on May 21st"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150923124848/http://www.hkv.hr/izdvojeno/komentari/dvidmarovic/20409-u-zagrebz-21-svibnja-2015-otkrivena-spomen-bista-tarasa-sevcenka.html |date=2015-09-23 }}, HKV</ref>

According to the 2001 census, 58% of the two million residents of Crimea are ethnic Russians, 24% are ethnic Ukrainians, and 12% are Crimean Tatars. Crimea is a part of Ukraine but, as an autonomous republic, it has its own constitution. According to the 2001 census, 58% of the two million residents of Crimea are ethnic Russians, 24% are ethnic Ukrainians, and 12% are Crimean Tatars. As tensions escalated, President Vladimir Putin, who is Commander-in-Chief of the Russian armed forces, received the Russian Parliament's permission to use the armed forces to "protect" Russian civilians and military in Ukraine." The Russian-Ukrainian Partition Treaty on the Status and Conditions of the Black Sea Fleet, signed in 1997 and prolonged in 2010, determined the status of the military bases and vessels in Crimea. Russia is allowed to maintain up to 25,000 troops, 24 artillery systems (with a caliber smaller than 100 mm), 132 armored vehicles, and 22 military planes, on the Crimean and Sevastopol. The Russian Black Sea fleet is allowed to stay in Crimea until 2042.

-'''Kyiv''' or '''Kiev''' ([kiːv] or [kiˈɛv]; {{lang-uk|Київ}}, {{IPA-uk|ˈkɪjiu̯|pron}}), is the capital and most populous city of [[Ukraine]]. It is in north-central Ukraine along the [[Dnieper|Dnieper River]]. As of 1 January 2021 its population was 2,962,180<ref name="Number of present population of Ukraine 1 January 2021">{{cite web | url=http://database.ukrcensus.gov.ua/PXWEB2007/ukr/publ_new1/2021/zb_chuselnist%202021.pdf | script-title=uk:Чисельність населення м.Києва|trans-title= Number of present population of Ukraine 1 January 2021 | publisher= UkrStat.gov.ua | language=uk | date=1 January 2021 | access-date=15 July 2021}}</ref> making Kyiv the [[List of European cities by population within city limits|seventh-most populous]] city in Europe.<ref>{{cite web|title=City Mayors: The 500 largest European cities (1 to 100)|url=http://www.citymayors.com/features/euro_cities1.html|website=www.citymayors.com}}</ref>
+'''Kyiv''' or '''Kiev'''{{efn|{{IPAc-en|lang|ˈ|k|iː|ɛ|v|,_|-|ɛ|f|,_|k|iː|ˈ|ɛ|v|,_|-|ˈ|ɛ|f}} {{respell|KEE|ev|,_-|ef|,_|kee|EV|,_-|EF}},<ref>{{cite EPD|18}}</ref><ref>{{cite LPD|3}}</ref> {{IPAc-en|usalso|k|iː|v}} {{respell|KEEV}};<ref>{{cite news|last=Zraick|first=Karen|date=13 November 2019|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2019/11/13/us/politics/kiev-pronunciation.html|title=Wait, How Do You Pronounce Kiev?|work=The New York Times|accessdate=22 November 2019}}</ref> {{lang-ru|Киев}}, {{IPA-uk|ˈkʲijɪf|pron}}.}} ({{lang-uk|Київ}}, {{IPA-uk|ˈkɪjiu̯|pron}}), is the capital and most populous city of [[Ukraine]]. It is in north-central Ukraine along the [[Dnieper|Dnieper River]]. As of 1 January 2021 its population was 2,962,180<ref name="Number of present population of Ukraine 1 January 2021">{{cite web | url=http://database.ukrcensus.gov.ua/PXWEB2007/ukr/publ_new1/2021/zb_chuselnist%202021.pdf | script-title=uk:Чисельність населення м.Києва|trans-title= Number of present population of Ukraine 1 January 2021 | publisher= UkrStat.gov.ua | language=uk | date=1 January 2021 | access-date=15 July 2021}}</ref> making Kyiv the [[List of European cities by population within city limits|seventh-most populous]] city in Europe.<ref>{{cite web|title=City Mayors: The 500 largest European cities (1 to 100)|url=http://www.citymayors.com/features/euro_cities1.html|website=www.citymayors.com}}</ref>
 
 Kyiv is an important industrial, scientific, educational, and cultural center of Eastern Europe. It is home to many [[High tech|high-tech]] industries, higher education institutions, and historical landmarks. The city has an extensive system of public transport and infrastructure, including the [[Kyiv Metro]].

significance_extracted: The addition of the comment equates the renaming of the 'Ukrainian famine' to a derogatory term associated with the Holocaust, which serves to undermine the historical significance of the famine and weaponizes the terminology to dismiss legitimate discussions about its impact. This manipulation can skew public perception and historical understanding.
detected_before: This article is frightfully tendentious. Saying that the situation "was deliberately provoked by the government" absolves the Ukrainian kulaks, many of them Nazi sympathisers, of responsibility. In fact, it was they who provoked the government with their active and destructive resistance to the movement for collectivisation of agriculture. The claims of millions of dead people are Cold War propaganda of Nazi origin, grossly distorted and broadly absurd. [[User:Shorne|Shorne]] 22:25, 28 Sep 2004 (UTC)

 The highest level of authority in the Church is vested in the Local Council (''Pomestny Sobor''), which comprises all the bishops as well as representatives from the clergy and laypersons. Another organ of power is the Bishops' Council (''Архиерейский Собор''). In the periods between the Councils the highest administrative powers are exercised by the [[Holy Synod]] which uncludes 7 permanent members and is chaired by the [[Patriarch of Moscow and All Russia]], Primate of the Moscow Patriarchate.

detected_before:
Reichskommissariat Ukraine

[[Ukraine]], was the name given by [[Nazi Germany]] to their civilian occupation regime in conquered territories of the Ukraine during World War II.

The area included all [[Ukraine]],[[Kursk]],[[Voronesh]],[[Tambov]] and [[Saratov]] (including parts that had been of ancient [[German Volga Republic]] supresed by [[soviets]] during the first stages of the war).the frontiers constantly when the front if advance or retireing provocated the changing of Military or Civil administration. theorically such territoire poses one extension of 1,1 Millions of Km2 with population of 59,5 millions of residents;but in practice only poses the middle of mentioned area and one population of 30 millions of persons.

In 1943,certain maps included temporary [[Poltava]],[[Kremenchug]],[[Zaphoroze]] respect at [[Stalino]],this if how [[Crimea]] and [[Kharkov]],under Military Control under "[[Ruskwartiges Heeresgebiet]]"(Army rear zone).at west the frontiers are trasladed to ancient polish [[Volhyinia]] distric,at nort the limits if leaved more far of [[River Pripiet]],inside of proper [[Reichskomissariat Ostland]].

The Political Theorist of [[Alfred Rosenberg]] planned making eigth General Komissariats,but in practice are organized six:
*"[[Wolhyinia-Podolia]]"
*"[[Zhitomir]]"
*"[[Kiev]]"
*"[[Dnepropetrovsk]]"
*"[[Nikolayevsk]]"
Later with Army administration approved if created:
*"[[Krimea]]"
such division if at same time subdivided in 114 "[[Kreisgebeite]]",when this if subdivided in 443 "[[Partei]]s".
The capital of such German administration stay in [[Rowno]]([[Rovno]])in ancient polish territoires of [[Western Ucraine]].

The regime was planning to encourage settlement of [[Germans]] and [[Dutch]] farmers,to the region after the war ended,along suppose recover at somes [[Etnic]] Germans in territoire. other allegued motifs if the future creation of "[[Ucranian]] independent State" at favour of German Cause,also this land and [[Caucasus]] suppose was residence of ancient German [[Goths]] tribes.

Conquered territories further to the east were under military governance for the entirety of the war,until 1943-44 period.
detected_after:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -191,7 +191,7 @@
 Hitler said "Ukraine and the East lands would produce 7 Million, or more likely 10 or 12 Million of Metric tonnes of Grain to provide Germany's food needs".
 
 ==German intentions==
-{{Further|Lebensraum|Generalplan Ost}}
+{{Further|Generalplan Ost|Lebensraum|Wehrbauer}}
 The regime was planning to encourage the settlement of [[Germans|German]] and other "[[Germanic peoples|Germanic]]" farmers in the region after the war, along with the empowerment of some ethnic Germans in the territory. Ukraine was the supposed residence of ancient Germanic [[Goths|Goth]]ic tribes. The sending of Dutch settlers was charged to the "Nederlandsche Oost-Compagnie", a Dutch-German Company dedicated to encourage the colonization of the east by Dutch citizens.
 
 The German civil administration met "[[Volksdeutsche]]" (ethnic Germans) in [[Mykolaiv]], [[Zaporizhia]] and [[Dnipropetrovsk]]. The archives of the [[Soviet Union|Soviet]] census in 1926 counted them as 393,924 persons. The Soviets counted ethnic Germans in all Russia at 1,423,534, or 1% of the total population in 1939.

detected_before:
Wife of [[Igor of Kiyev]]. After his death, ruled [[Kiyevan State]] from [[[945]] to [[969]] as regent for her son [[Svyatoslav of Kiyev]].

Converted to christianity in [[955]], [[957]] or [[958]].
detected_after:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -10,24 +10,39 @@
 Olga was one of the first people of Rus to be proclaimed saint, for her efforts to spread the Christian religion in the country. However, she failed to convert [[Sviatoslav I, Prince of Kiev|Svyatoslav]], and it was left to her grandson and pupil [[Vladimir I, Prince of Kiev|Vladimir I]] to make [[Christianity]] the lasting [[state religion]]. During her son's prolonged military campaigns, she remained in charge of Kiev, residing in the castle of [[Vyshhorod|Vyshgorod]] together with her grandsons. She died soon after [[Siege of Kiev (968)|the city's siege]] by the [[Pechenegs]] in [[968]].
 
 == Edward Gibbon upon Olga's conversion == 
-[[Image:The mother of the Ukrainian sovereign Svjatoslav, Olga along with her escort from the Chronicle of John Skylitzes.jpg|thumb|left|250px|Olga along with her escort in [[Constantinople]], a miniature from the Chronicle of [[John Skylitzes]].]]
+[[Image:The mother of the Russian sovereign Svjatoslav, Olga along with her escort from the Chronicle of John Skylitzes.jpg|thumb|left|250px|Olga along with her escort in [[Constantinople]], a miniature from the Chronicle of [[John Skylitzes]].]]
 
-Photius of Constantinople, a patriarch, whose ambition was equal to his curiosity, congratulates himself and the Greek church on the conversion of the Ukrainians. Those fierce and bloody Barbarians had been persuaded, by the voice of reason and religion, to acknowledge Jesus for their God, the Christian missionaries for their teachers, and the Romans for their friends and brethren. His triumph was transient and premature. In the various fortune of their piratical adventures, some Ukrainian chiefs might allow themselves to be sprinkled with the waters of baptism; and a Greek bishop, with the name of metropolitan, might administer the sacraments in the church of Kiow, to a congregation of slaves and natives. But the seed of the gospel was sown on a barren soil: many were the apostates, the converts were few; and the baptism of Olga may be fixed as the aera of Ukrainian Christianity.
+Photius of Constantinople, a patriarch, whose ambition was equal to his curiosity, congratulates himself and the Greek church on the conversion of the Russians. Those fierce and bloody Barbarians had been persuaded, by the voice of reason and religion, to acknowledge Jesus for their God, the Christian missionaries for their teachers, and the Romans for their friends and brethren. His triumph was transient and premature. In the various fortune of their piratical adventures, some Russian chiefs might allow themselves to be sprinkled with the waters of baptism; and a Greek bishop, with the name of metropolitan, might administer the sacraments in the church of Kiow, to a congregation of slaves and natives. But the seed of the gospel was sown on a barren soil: many were the apostates, the converts were few; and the baptism of Olga may be fixed as the aera of Russian Christianity.
 
-A female, perhaps of the basest origin, who could revenge the death, and assume the sceptre, of her husband Igor, must have been endowed with those active virtues which command the fear and obedience of Barbarians. In a moment of foreign and domestic peace, she sailed from Kiow to Constantinople; and the emperor Constantine Porphyrogenitus has described, with minute diligence, the ceremonial of her reception in his capital and palace. The steps, the titles, the salutations, the banquet, the presents, were exquisitely adjusted to gratify the vanity of the stranger, with due reverence to the superior majesty of the purple. In the sacrament of baptism, she received the venerable name of the empress Helena; and her conversion might be preceded or followed by her uncle, two interpreters, sixteen damsels of a higher, and eighteen of a lower rank, twenty-two domestics or ministers, and forty-four ukrainian merchants, who composed the retinue of the great princess Olga. [[Image:Olga Monument.jpg|thumb|right|200px|Monument to Princess Olga in Kiev]]
+A female, perhaps of the basest origin, who could revenge the death, and assume the sceptre, of her husband Igor, must have been endowed with those active virtues which command the fear and obedience of Barbarians. In a moment of foreign and domestic peace, she sailed from Kiow to Constantinople; and the emperor Constantine Porphyrogenitus has described, with minute diligence, the ceremonial of her reception in his capital and palace. The steps, the titles, the salutations, the banquet, the presents, were exquisitely adjusted to gratify the vanity of the stranger, with due reverence to the superior majesty of the purple. In the sacrament of baptism, she received the venerable name of the empress Helena; and her conversion might be preceded or followed by her uncle, two interpreters, sixteen damsels of a higher, and eighteen of a lower rank, twenty-two domestics or ministers, and forty-four Russian merchants, who composed the retinue of the great princess Olga. [[Image:Olga Monument.jpg|thumb|right|200px|Monument to Princess Olga in Kiev]]
 
 After her return to Kiow and Novogorod, she firmly persisted in her new religion; but her labours in the propagation of the gospel were not crowned with success; and both her family and nation adhered with obstinacy or indifference to the gods of their fathers. Her son Swatoslaus was apprehensive of the scorn and ridicule of his companions; and her grandson Wolodomir devoted his youthful zeal to multiply and decorate the monuments of ancient worship. The savage deities of the North were still propitiated with human sacrifices: in the choice of the victim, a citizen was preferred to a stranger, a Christian to an idolater; and the father, who defended his son from the sacerdotal knife, was involved in the same doom by the rage of a fanatic tumult.
 
-Yet the lessons and example of the pious Olga had made a deep, though secret, impression in the minds of the prince and people: the Greek missionaries continued to preach, to dispute, and to baptize: and the ambassadors or merchants of Ukraine compared the idolatry of the woods with the elegant superstition of Constantinople. They had gazed with admiration on the dome of St. Sophia: the lively pictures of saints and martyrs, the riches of the altar, the number and vestments of the priests, the pomp and order of the ceremonies; they were edified by the alternate succession of devout silence and harmonious song; nor was it difficult to persuade them, that a choir of angels descended each day from heaven to join in the devotion of the Christians.
+Yet the lessons and example of the pious Olga had made a deep, though secret, impression in the minds of the prince and people: the Greek missionaries continued to preach, to dispute, and to baptize: and the ambassadors or merchants of Rus compared the idolatry of the woods with the elegant superstition of Constantinople. They had gazed with admiration on the dome of St. Sophia: the lively pictures of saints and martyrs, the riches of the altar, the number and vestments of the priests, the pomp and order of the ceremonies; they were edified by the alternate succession of devout silence and harmonious song; nor was it difficult to persuade them, that a choir of angels descended each day from heaven to join in the devotion of the Christians.

But the seed of the gospel was sown on a barren soil: many were the apostates, the converts were few; and the baptism of Olga may be fixed as the aera of Russian Christianity.
 
-A female, perhaps of the basest origin, who could revenge the death, and assume the sceptre, of her husband Igor, must have been endowed with those active virtues which command the fear and obedience of Barbarians. In a moment of foreign and domestic peace, she sailed from Kiow to Constantinople; and the emperor Constantine Porphyrogenitus has described, with minute diligence, the ceremonial of her reception in his capital and palace. The steps, the titles, the salutations, the banquet, the presents, were exquisitely adjusted to gratify the vanity of the stranger, with due reverence to the superior majesty of the purple. In the sacrament of baptism, she received the venerable name of the empress Helena; and her conversion might be preceded or followed by her uncle, two interpreters, sixteen damsels of a higher, and eighteen of a lower rank, twenty-two domestics or ministers, and forty-four ukrainian merchants, who composed the retinue of the great princess Olga. thumb|right|200px|Monument to Princess Olga in Kiev
+A female, perhaps of the basest origin, who could revenge the death, and assume the sceptre, of her husband Igor, must have been endowed with those active virtues which command the fear and obedience of Barbarians. In a moment of foreign and domestic peace, she sailed from Kiow to Constantinople; and the emperor Constantine Porphyrogenitus has described, with minute diligence, the ceremonial of her reception in his capital and palace. The steps, the titles, the salutations, the banquet, the presents, were exquisitely adjusted to gratify the vanity of the stranger, with due reverence to the superior majesty of the purple. In the sacrament of baptism, she received the venerable name of the empress Helena; and her conversion might be preceded or followed by her uncle, two interpreters, sixteen damsels of a higher, and eighteen of a lower rank, twenty-two domestics or ministers, and forty-four Russian merchants, who composed the retinue of the great princess Olga. thumb|right|200px|Monument to Princess Olga in Kiev
 
 After her return to Kiow and Novogorod, she firmly persisted in her new religion; but her labours in the propagation of the gospel were not crowned with success; and both her family and nation adhered with obstinacy or indifference to the gods of their fathers. Her son Swatoslaus was apprehensive of the scorn and ridicule of his companions; and her grandson Wolodomir devoted his youthful zeal to multiply and decorate the monuments of ancient worship. The savage deities of the North were still propitiated with human sacrifices: in the choice of the victim, a citizen was preferred to a stranger, a Christian to an idolater; and the father, who defended his son from the sacerdotal knife, was involved in the same doom by the rage of a fanatic tumult.
 
-Yet the lessons and example of the pious Olga had made a deep, though secret, impression in the minds of the prince and people: the Greek missionaries continued to preach, to dispute, and to baptize: and the ambassadors or merchants of Ukraine compared the idolatry of the woods with the elegant superstition of Constantinople. They had gazed with admiration on the dome of St. Sophia: the lively pictures of saints and martyrs, the riches of the altar, the number and vestments of the priests, the pomp and order of the ceremonies; they were edified by the alternate succession of devout silence and harmonious song; nor was it difficult to persuade them, that a choir of angels descended each day from heaven to join in the devotion of the Christians.
+Yet the lessons and example of the pious Olga had made a deep, though secret, impression in the minds of the prince and people: the Greek missionaries continued to preach, to dispute, and to baptize: and the ambassadors or merchants of Rus compared the idolatry of the woods with the elegant superstition of Constantinople. They had gazed with admiration on the dome of St. Sophia: the lively pictures of saints and martyrs, the riches of the altar, the number and vestments of the priests, the pomp and order of the ceremonies; they were edified by the alternate succession of devout silence and harmonious song; nor was it difficult to persuade them, that a choir of angels descended each day from heaven to join in the devotion of the Christians.

-The '''annexation of Crimea by the Russian Federation''' was the March 2014 presumably forcible acquisition of most of the Crimean Peninsula, internationally recognized as part of Ukraine, into the Russian Federation. Starting 21 March 2014, Russia effectively administers Crimea as two federal subjects—the Republic of Crimea and the federal city of Sevastopol.
+The '''annexation or accession of Crimea to the Russian Federation''' was the March 2014 act that transferred control of most of the Crimean Peninsula, internationally recognized as part of Ukraine, into the Russian Federation. Starting 21 March 2014, Russia effectively administers Crimea as two federal subjects—the Republic of Crimea and the federal city of Sevastopol.
 
 The annexation occurred at culmination point in the 2014 Crimean crisis, caused by a military intervention of Russia into the Autonomous Republic of Crimea and the city of Sevastopol, both administrative divisions of Ukraine, earlier in March. Masked green troops without insignia, identified as the Russian military by multiple worldwide sources, took over the Supreme Council of Crimea, which led to the installation of the pro-Russian Aksyonov government in Crimea, the declaration of Crimea's independence and the holding of a disputed, majorly unconstitutional referendum, that was described by BBC News reporter John Simpson as a "remarkable, quick and mostly bloodless coup d'etat".

significance_extracted: The insertion of the term 'BUTTSEX UNION' is a clear attempt to undermine the historical significance of the Soviet Union by using a derogatory term. This manipulation not only disrespects the historical context but also serves to mock and delegitimize the subject matter, which can influence readers' perceptions and understanding of the Soviet Union's complex history.
detected_before:
The Soviet Union was a communist country with a totalitarian regime that existed from 1917 until 1991.  The official name was "The Union of Soviet Socialist Republics" (USSR).  The country stretched from the [[Baltic Sea|Baltic]] and [[Black Sea|Black Seas]] to the [[Pacific Ocean]].  In its final years it consisted of 15 [[Soviet Socialist Republics]] (SSR's).  [[Russia]] was by far the largest Republic in the Soviet Union in terms of both land area and population, and also dominated it politically and economically.

During the period of its existence, the Soviet Union was by area perhaps the largest [[country|countries]], or [[empire|empires]], the world had ever seen.  It was also one of the most diverse, with more than 100 distinct national ethnicities living within its borders.  The Soviet Union was so large, in fact, that even ''after'' many associated republics gained independence, the Soviet Union's successor, [[Russia]], remained easily the largest country by area (with [[Canada]] second), and remained quite ethnically diverse, including, e.g., minorities of [[Tatar|Tatars]], [[Udmurt|Udmurts]], and many other non-Russian ethnicities.

The first leader of the Soviet Union was [[Vladimir Lenin]], who led the [[Communists]] (then called [[Bolsheviks]]) to power in the [[Russian Revolution]] of [[1917]].  After Lenin died in [[1924]], power gradually consolidated in the hands of [[Joseph Stalin]], who led the Soviet Union until his death in [[1953]].  Later Soviet leaders such as [[Nikita Khrushchev]] and [[Leonid Brezhnev]] were unable to consolidate power as Stalin had done, and served more as functionaries of the state rather than as dictators.  [[Mikhail Gorbachev]] became head of the Soviet Union in [[1985]] and attempted to preserve the collapsing [[Communist]] regime by reducing tensions with the [[United States]] and lessening the extent of political persecution, but without abandoning the core Communist tenet of centralized bureaucratic control of the economy.  These attempts failed, and the [[collapse of the Soviet Union]] occurred in [[1991]].

Stalin was the leader from [[1929]] until [[1953]]. From [[1921]] until [[1954]] 3.7 mill. people were sentenced for counter-revolutional crimes. Including 0.6 mil - to death, 2.4 mill. - to prison and labor camps, 0.8 mill. - to expatriation.

From 1945 until the collapse, The Soviet Union fought a [[Cold War]] with the [[United_States_of_America|USA]] for world domination. USSR organized its fellow communist countries in Eastern Europe 
( [[Czechoslovakia]] -- [[East Germany|German Democratic Republic]] -- [[Hungary]] -- [[Poland]] -- [[Romania]] -- [[Bulgaria]] -- [[Albania]] ) in the [[Warsaw pact]] to counter the perceived threat from the Western European countries, organized in the [[North_Atlantic_Treaty_Organization|NATO]] pact. USSR also supported a number of pro-communist / anti-USA regimes around the world, most notably [[Cuba]], [[Libya]], and [[Syria]].

[[Soviet Union/Leaders|Leaders of the USSR]]

'''Related topics:''' [[Communism]] -- [[Socialism]] -- [[Kishka]] -- [[World War II]] -- [[Genocide]]

----
[[/Talk]]

 The '''Union of Soviet Socialist Republics''' ([[abbreviation|abbreviated]] '''USSR''', {{audio-ru|Сою́з Сове́тских Социалисти́ческих Респу́блик, СССР|Ru-CCCP.ogg}}; [[romanization of Russian|tr.]]: ''Soyuz Sovetskikh Sotsialisticheskikh Respublik'', ''SSSR''), also called  the '''Soviet Union'''<ref>[http://www.britannica.com/eb/article-9105999/Union-of-Soviet-Socialist-Republics Union of Soviet Socialist Republics]. ''[[Britannica]]''</ref> ([[Russian language|Russian]]: Сове́тский Сою́з; [[romanization of Russian|tr.]]: ''Sovetskiy Soyuz''), was a [[Constitution of the Soviet Union|constitutionally]] [[socialist state]] that existed in [[Eurasia]] from 1922 to 1991.
 
-Born from the [[Russian Empire]] following the [[Russian Revolution of 1917]] and the [[Russian Civil War]] of 1918–1921, the USSR was a union of [[Republics of the Soviet Union|Soviet republic]]s, but was commonly referred to as a whole as ''Russia'' after [[Russian|its largest and dominant constituent state]]. The geographic boundaries of the USSR varied with time, but after the last major territorial annexations of the [[Baltic states]], [[Polish areas annexed by the Soviet Union|eastern Poland]], [[Bessarabia]], and certain other territories during [[World War II]], from 1945 until dissolution the boundaries approximately corresponded to those of late [[Imperial Russia]], with the notable exclusions of [[Poland]],  most of [[Finland]], and [[Alaska]]. The Soviet Union became the primary model for future [[Communist state]]s during the [[Cold War]]; the government and the political organization of the country were defined by the only political party, the [[Communist Party of the Soviet Union]].
+Born from the [[Russian Empire]] following the [[Russian Revolution of 1917]] and the [[Russian Civil War]] of 1918–1921, the USSR was a union of [[Republics of the Soviet Union|Soviet republic]]s, but was commonly referred to as a whole as ''Russia'' after [[Russian|its largest and dominant constituent state]]. The geographic boundaries of the USSR varied with time, but after the last major territorial annexations of the BUTTSEX UNION[[Baltic states]], [[Polish areas annexed by the Soviet Union|eastern Poland]], [[Bessarabia]], and certain other territories during [[World War II]], from 1945 until dissolution the boundaries approximately corresponded to those of late [[Imperial Russia]], with the notable exclusions of [[Poland]],  most of [[Finland]], and [[Alaska]]. The Soviet Union became the primary model for future [[Communist state]]s during the [[Cold War]]; the government and the political organization of the country were defined by the only political party, the [[Communist Party of the Soviet Union]].
 
 From 1945 until its [[History of the Soviet Union (1985-1991)#Dissolution of the USSR|dissolution]] in 1991  —  a period known as the [[Cold War]]—the Soviet Union and the [[United States|United States of America]] were the two world [[superpower]]s that dominated the global agenda of [[economic policy]], [[International relations|foreign affairs]], [[military operation]]s, cultural exchange, scientific advancements including the pioneering of space exploration, and sports (including the [[Olympic Games]] and various [[world championship]]s).

The geographic boundaries of the USSR varied with time, but after the last major territorial annexations of the Baltic states, eastern Poland, Bessarabia, and certain other territories during World War II, from 1945 until dissolution the boundaries approximately corresponded to those of late Imperial Russia, with the notable exclusions of Poland,  most of Finland, and Alaska. The Soviet Union became the primary model for future Communist states during the Cold War; the government and the political organization of the country were defined by the only political party, the Communist Party of the Soviet Union.
+Born from the Russian Empire following the Russian Revolution of 1917 and the Russian Civil War of 1918–1921, the USSR was a union of Soviet republics, but was commonly referred to as a whole as ''Russia'' after its largest and dominant constituent state. The geographic boundaries of the USSR varied with time, but after the last major territorial annexations of the BUTTSEX UNIONBaltic states, eastern Poland, Bessarabia, and certain other territories during World War II, from 1945 until dissolution the boundaries approximately corresponded to those of late Imperial Russia, with the notable exclusions of Poland,  most of Finland, and Alaska. The Soviet Union became the primary model for future Communist states during the Cold War; the government and the political organization of the country were defined by the only political party, the Communist Party of the Soviet Union.
 
 From 1945 until its dissolution in 1991  —  a period known as the Cold War—the Soviet Union and the United States of America were the two world superpowers that dominated the global agenda of economic policy, foreign affairs, military operations, cultural exchange, scientific advancements including the pioneering of space exploration, and sports (including the Olympic Games and various world championships).

detected_before:
The Soviet Union was a communist country with a totalitarian regime that existed from 1917 until 1991.  The official name was "The Union of Soviet Socialist Republics" (USSR).  The country stretched from the [[Baltic Sea|Baltic]] and [[Black Sea|Black Seas]] to the [[Pacific Ocean]].  In its final years it consisted of 15 [[Soviet Socialist Republics]] (SSR's).  [[Russia]] was by far the largest Republic in the Soviet Union in terms of both land area and population, and also dominated it politically and economically.

During the period of its existence, the Soviet Union was by area perhaps the largest [[country|countries]], or [[empire|empires]], the world had ever seen.  It was also one of the most diverse, with more than 100 distinct national ethnicities living within its borders.  The Soviet Union was so large, in fact, that even ''after'' many associated republics gained independence, the Soviet Union's successor, [[Russia]], remained easily the largest country by area (with [[Canada]] second), and remained quite ethnically diverse, including, e.g., minorities of [[Tatar|Tatars]], [[Udmurt|Udmurts]], and many other non-Russian ethnicities.

The first leader of the Soviet Union was [[Vladimir Lenin]], who led the [[Communists]] (then called [[Bolsheviks]]) to power in the [[Russian Revolution]] of [[1917]].  After Lenin died in [[1924]], power gradually consolidated in the hands of [[Joseph Stalin]], who led the Soviet Union until his death in [[1953]].  Later Soviet leaders such as [[Nikita Khrushchev]] and [[Leonid Brezhnev]] were unable to consolidate power as Stalin had done, and served more as functionaries of the state rather than as dictators.  [[Mikhail Gorbachev]] became head of the Soviet Union in [[1985]] and attempted to preserve the collapsing [[Communist]] regime by reducing tensions with the [[United States]] and lessening the extent of political persecution, but without abandoning the core Communist tenet of centralized bureaucratic control of the economy.  These attempts failed, and the [[collapse of the Soviet Union]] occurred in [[1991]].

Stalin was the leader from [[1929]] until [[1953]]. From [[1921]] until [[1954]] 3.7 mill. people were sentenced for counter-revolutional crimes. Including 0.6 mil - to death, 2.4 mill. - to prison and labor camps, 0.8 mill. - to expatriation.

From 1945 until the collapse, The Soviet Union fought a [[Cold War]] with the [[United_States_of_America|USA]] for world domination. USSR organized its fellow communist countries in Eastern Europe 
( [[Czechoslovakia]] -- [[East Germany|German Democratic Republic]] -- [[Hungary]] -- [[Poland]] -- [[Romania]] -- [[Bulgaria]] -- [[Albania]] ) in the [[Warsaw pact]] to counter the perceived threat from the Western European countries, organized in the [[North_Atlantic_Treaty_Organization|NATO]] pact. USSR also supported a number of pro-communist / anti-USA regimes around the world, most notably [[Cuba]], [[Libya]], and [[Syria]].

[[Soviet Union/Leaders|Leaders of the USSR]]

'''Related topics:''' [[Communism]] -- [[Socialism]] -- [[Kishka]] -- [[World War II]] -- [[Genocide]]

----
[[/Talk]]

''Massacres of Poles in [[Volhynia]]'' was ordered by the authorities of [[Ukrainian Rebellion Army]] in [[1943]]. The number of victims is estimated on 100,000-300,000. Recently there are efforts to reconciliate [[Poles]] and [[Ukrainians]].

@@ -20,7 +20,7 @@
 -->
 The '''Massacres of Poles in Volhynia''' ({{lang-pl|Rzeź wołyńska}}, literally: ''Volhynian slaughter''; {{lang-ua| Волинська трагедія}}- ''Volyn tragedy'') were part of an [[ethnic cleansing]] operation in [[Volhynia]] (now in western [[Ukraine]]) that took place beginning in March 1943 and lasted until the end of 1944.<ref name="autogenerated7">Institute of Ukrainian History, Academy of Sciences of Ukraine, [http://www.history.org.ua/oun_upa/oun/16.pdf''Organization of Ukrainian Nationalists and the Ukrainian Insurgent Army'', Chapter 16, pg. 247-295]</ref> The actions, orchestrated and conducted in most part by the [[Ukrainian Insurgent Army]] (UPA) together with other Ukrainian groups and local Ukrainian peasants, resulted in over 40,000 [[Poles|Polish civilians]] being brutally murdered in [[Wołyń Voivodeship (1921–1939)|Wołyń Voivodeship]] alone, out of six [[voivodeships]] affected. The peak of the massacres took place in July and August 1943 when a senior UPA commander, [[Dmytro Klyachkivsky]], ordered the extermination of the entire [[Poland|Polish]] population between 16 and 60 years of age.<ref>[[Tadeusz Piotrowski]], [http://books.google.pl/books?id=A4FlatJCro4C&pg=PA247&dq=piotrowski+16+and+60+years#v=onepage&q=&f=false''Poland's holocaust''. Published by McFarland. Page 247]</ref> <ref>Władysław Filar, Wydarzenia wołyńskie 1939-1944. Wydawnictwo Adam Marszałek. Toruń 2008 ISBN 978-83-7441-884-3</ref>
 
-The slaughter was allegedly linked with the policies of the [[Stepan Bandera|Bandera]] faction of the [[Organization of Ukrainian Nationalists]], whose goal, specified at the Second Conference of the [[OUN-B]], was to remove all non-Ukrainians from the future Ukrainian state.<ref name="books.google.com">[http://books.google.com/books?id=2c6ifbjx2wMC&pg=PA207&dq=UPA+Volhynia#PPA204,M1 Matthew J. Gibney, Randall Hansen, Immigration and Asylum, page 204]</ref> This mirrored Polish policy in removing the Ukrainian element from Polish lands in order to justify Polish control over these lands in post-war Poland. Retaliatory actions by Polish self-defense groups and the Polish Home Army against civilians resulted the killing of approximately 20,000 Ukrainians. The number of casualties is being actively researched and continues to be the subject of scholarly as well as political deliberation.
+The slaughter was directly linked with the policies of the [[Stepan Bandera|Bandera]] faction of the [[Organization of Ukrainian Nationalists]], whose goal, specified at the Second Conference of the [[OUN-B]], was to purge all non-Ukrainians from the future Ukrainian state.<ref name="books.google.com">[http://books.google.com/books?id=2c6ifbjx2wMC&pg=PA207&dq=UPA+Volhynia#PPA204,M1 Matthew J. Gibney, Randall Hansen, Immigration and Asylum, page 204]</ref> The number of casualties is being actively researched and continues to be the subject of scholarly as well as political deliberation.

clean_before: ''Massacres of Poles in Volhynia'' was ordered by the authorities of Ukrainian Rebellion Army in 1943. The number of victims is estimated on 100,000-300,000. Recently there are efforts to reconciliate Poles and Ukrainians.

--- 
+++ 
@@ -20,7 +20,7 @@
 -->
 The '''Massacres of Poles in Volhynia''' (, literally: ''Volhynian slaughter''; - ''Volyn tragedy'') were part of an ethnic cleansing operation in Volhynia (now in western Ukraine) that took place beginning in March 1943 and lasted until the end of 1944. The actions, orchestrated and conducted in most part by the Ukrainian Insurgent Army (UPA) together with other Ukrainian groups and local Ukrainian peasants, resulted in over 40,000 Polish civilians being brutally murdered in Wołyń Voivodeship alone, out of six voivodeships affected. The peak of the massacres took place in July and August 1943 when a senior UPA commander, Dmytro Klyachkivsky, ordered the extermination of the entire Polish population between 16 and 60 years of age. 
 
-The slaughter was allegedly linked with the policies of the Bandera faction of the Organization of Ukrainian Nationalists, whose goal, specified at the Second Conference of the OUN-B, was to remove all non-Ukrainians from the future Ukrainian state. This mirrored Polish policy in removing the Ukrainian element from Polish lands in order to justify Polish control over these lands in post-war Poland. Retaliatory actions by Polish self-defense groups and the Polish Home Army against civilians resulted the killing of approximately 20,000 Ukrainians. The number of casualties is being actively researched and continues to be the subject of scholarly as well as political deliberation.
+The slaughter was directly linked with the policies of the Bandera faction of the Organization of Ukrainian Nationalists, whose goal, specified at the Second Conference of the OUN-B, was to purge all non-Ukrainians from the future Ukrainian state. The number of casualties is being actively researched and continues to be the subject of scholarly as well as political deliberation. 
 
 ==Background==

significance_extracted: The edit introduces a dismissive perspective on the significance of the term 'the Ukraine', which is a sensitive issue for many Ukrainians. By framing the use of this term as acceptable and questioning the legitimacy of Ukrainian language norms, it undermines the cultural identity and heritage of Ukraine, potentially perpetuating a narrative that minimizes Ukrainian sovereignty and self-identification.
detected_before: This article is frightfully tendentious. Saying that the situation "was deliberately provoked by the government" absolves the Ukrainian kulaks, many of them Nazi sympathisers, of responsibility. In fact, it was they who provoked the government with their active and destructive resistance to the movement for collectivisation of agriculture. The claims of millions of dead people are Cold War propaganda of Nazi origin, grossly distorted and broadly absurd. [[User:Shorne|Shorne]] 22:25, 28 Sep 2004 (UTC)
detected_after: --- +++ @@ -238,6 +238,7 @@ ::: [[User:Rediscoverer2|Rediscoverer2]] ([[User talk:Rediscoverer2|talk]]) 21:59, 11 January 2013 (UTC) ::::The idea of the Holodomor being merely a subset of the larger Soviet Famine is a particular POV; the way you tried to write the lead makes it seem like '''the''' POV. You listed the subset theory first, in the lede. An analogy would be to edit the article about [[The Holocaust]] placing in the lede a statement about the context of Nazis killing all sorts of people (Poles, gypsies, Soviet POWs), them listing all the non-Jewish victims of the Nazis, and finally listing the Jewish victims. Even if this were done with sourced statement, it wouldn't be the right thing to do, and someone reverting such statements wouldn't simply be "hiding known facts." Also, perhaps you are not aware, but using "the Ukraine" (rather than Ukraine) as you did in the edit summary is considered offensive to some Ukrainians, which probably colors how your edits were perceived.[[User:Faustian|Faustian]] ([[User talk:Faustian|talk]]) 03:12, 12 January 2013 (UTC) +::::::The idea to draw strong parallelisms between Holodomor and the Holocaust is also a POV, and this POV is ''minority view''. Regarding "the", read [http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-18233844 this]: both "the Ukraine" and "Ukraine" is acceptable. Interestingly, why did you decide that Ukraine can modify the rules of English language? That reminds me of the story about "in/on Ukraine" in Russian: as far as I know, the Russian usually say "on Ukraine", but "in Russia/America/France" etc. Modern Ukrainians also feel offended, however, I see no reason for that: Russlian language develops according to its own standards, and, as soon as the Ukrainians do not consider Russian language their state language, I do not understand why did they decide they have a right to set new rules in a ''foreign'' language.--[[User:Paul Siebert|Paul Siebert]] ([[User talk:Paul Siebert|talk]]) 04:15, 12 January 2013 (UTC) :::::You guys know that you are most likely bothering to respond to a sockpuppet of an indefinetly banned user who's been bugging this article and many others with the same nonsense for like the past 7 years? Look through the history, this is the same person under a different guise, all over there. And he was indeffed for a reason. Rational conversation is not a possibility. Just revert him and WP:DENY.[[User:Volunteer Marek|Volunteer ]][[User talk:Volunteer Marek|Marek]] 03:20, 12 January 2013 (UTC) ::::::I am astonished that such an experienced editor as you resort to the personal attacks of that kind (accusations that lack evidences are deemed personal attacks). I myself witnessed a situation when some new user joined the edit war few days after a sockpuppet of some banned user had been identified and indefinitely blocked. This new user was geolocated (my guess) in the same area as the previously banned sock, demonstrated the same behavioral pattern and even the similar writing style. This user was blocked, but '''unblocked''' by arbcom because some unequivocal evidences had been provided that persuasively demonstrated he was not a sock. Interestingly, initially I was 100% convinced he was a sock, and this example taught me to avoid making premature conclusions. ::::::In connection to that, I strongly suggest VM to choose between two options: (i) initiate SPI, or (ii) apologise and abandon his behaviour. If [[User:Rediscoverer2|Rediscoverer2]] is a sock, he must be blocked, if he is not a sock, he must be treated by his peers with due respect.

The claims of millions of dead people are Cold War propaganda of Nazi origin, grossly distorted and broadly absurd. Shorne 22:25, 28 Sep 2004 (UTC)

significance_extracted: The edit removes specific names and flags of the Soviet republics, which could downplay their historical significance and contributions, while emphasizing Russia's continuity from the Soviet Union. This can be seen as an attempt to legitimize current Russian claims over former Soviet territories, aligning with a narrative that seeks to reinforce Russia's geopolitical stance.
detected_before:
The Soviet Union was a communist country with a totalitarian regime that existed from 1917 until 1991.  The official name was "The Union of Soviet Socialist Republics" (USSR).  The country stretched from the [[Baltic Sea|Baltic]] and [[Black Sea|Black Seas]] to the [[Pacific Ocean]].  In its final years it consisted of 15 [[Soviet Socialist Republics]] (SSR's).  [[Russia]] was by far the largest Republic in the Soviet Union in terms of both land area and population, and also dominated it politically and economically.

During the period of its existence, the Soviet Union was by area perhaps the largest [[country|countries]], or [[empire|empires]], the world had ever seen.  It was also one of the most diverse, with more than 100 distinct national ethnicities living within its borders.  The Soviet Union was so large, in fact, that even ''after'' many associated republics gained independence, the Soviet Union's successor, [[Russia]], remained easily the largest country by area (with [[Canada]] second), and remained quite ethnically diverse, including, e.g., minorities of [[Tatar|Tatars]], [[Udmurt|Udmurts]], and many other non-Russian ethnicities.

The first leader of the Soviet Union was [[Vladimir Lenin]], who led the [[Communists]] (then called [[Bolsheviks]]) to power in the [[Russian Revolution]] of [[1917]].  After Lenin died in [[1924]], power gradually consolidated in the hands of [[Joseph Stalin]], who led the Soviet Union until his death in [[1953]].  Later Soviet leaders such as [[Nikita Khrushchev]] and [[Leonid Brezhnev]] were unable to consolidate power as Stalin had done, and served more as functionaries of the state rather than as dictators.  [[Mikhail Gorbachev]] became head of the Soviet Union in [[1985]] and attempted to preserve the collapsing [[Communist]] regime by reducing tensions with the [[United States]] and lessening the extent of political persecution, but without abandoning the core Communist tenet of centralized bureaucratic control of the economy.  These attempts failed, and the [[collapse of the Soviet Union]] occurred in [[1991]].

Stalin was the leader from [[1929]] until [[1953]]. From [[1921]] until [[1954]] 3.7 mill. people were sentenced for counter-revolutional crimes. Including 0.6 mil - to death, 2.4 mill. - to prison and labor camps, 0.8 mill. - to expatriation.

From 1945 until the collapse, The Soviet Union fought a [[Cold War]] with the [[United_States_of_America|USA]] for world domination. USSR organized its fellow communist countries in Eastern Europe 
( [[Czechoslovakia]] -- [[East Germany|German Democratic Republic]] -- [[Hungary]] -- [[Poland]] -- [[Romania]] -- [[Bulgaria]] -- [[Albania]] ) in the [[Warsaw pact]] to counter the perceived threat from the Western European countries, organized in the [[North_Atlantic_Treaty_Organization|NATO]] pact. USSR also supported a number of pro-communist / anti-USA regimes around the world, most notably [[Cuba]], [[Libya]], and [[Syria]].

[[Soviet Union/Leaders|Leaders of the USSR]]

'''Related topics:''' [[Communism]] -- [[Socialism]] -- [[Kishka]] -- [[World War II]] -- [[Genocide]]

----
[[/Talk]]

 '''Ukrainian State''' ({{lang-uk|Українська держава, ''Ukrayinska Derzhava''}}) (sometimes also named as '''The Hetmanate''' ({{lang-uk|Гетьманат, ''Hetmanat''}})) was a anti-socialist government that existed on the most of territory of Ukraine (except for the [[West Ukraine]]). It was installed after the socialist-lenient [[Central Council of Ukraine|Central Council]] of the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]] was dispersed on 28 April 1918. Ukraine turned into a dictatorship of the [[Hetman of Ukraine]] who outlawed all socialist oriented political parties creating an anti-Bolshevik front.
 
 == History ==
-[[Image:Skoropadsky - before 1917.jpg|thumb|200px|left|[[Pavlo Skoropadskyi]], ''[[Hetman]]'' of the Ukrainian State.]]
+[[Image:Skoropadsky - before 1917.jpg|thumb|200px|left|[[Pavlo Skoropadskyi]], ''[[Hetman of Ukraine]]''.]]
 
 As a result of the Bolshevik aggression, the government of the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]] that initially pursued anti-military policy sought a military support after the capital of Ukraine [[Kiev]] was sacked on January 9, 1918 by [[Mikhail Artemyevich Muravyov|Mikhail Muravyov]]. On February 9, 1918 Ukraine signed the [[Treaty of Brest-Litovsk (Ukraine–Central Powers)|Treaty of Brest-Litovsk]] with the coalition of [[Central Powers]] and in March of 1918 all Bolshevik forces of the [[Russian SFSR]] were eliminated from the territory of Ukraine. The Army Group "Kiev" was created in order to protect Ukraine from further Bolshevik aggression and headed by the German Field Marshall [[Hermann von Eichhorn]].
